Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> 
> 
> On 2/13/07, Jeff Langr <jeff@... 
> <mailto:jeff%40langrsoft.com>> wrote:
>  > > Quoting Michael Feathers <mfeathers@... 
> <mailto:mfeathers%40mindspring.com>>:
>  > > True enough, but there's no particular reason why the logic has to be
>  > > private. I'd be leery of a class that generates HTML and sorts. If the
>  > > sort is an another class, it can be public and far easier to test.
>  >
>  > I've always wondered why most developers are highly offended by making
>  > things more public for purposes of testing
> 
> Here is my take: for the past twenty years, we have been taught the
> benefits of object-oriented programming and encapsulation, at school,
> in the workplace and in countless books and articles.
> 
> The emphasis on testing has only received more visibility in the past
> five years, and some of its principles are indeed at odds with some of
> the OO knowledge that has been pervading the software industry for two
> decades now.
> 
> After being told repeatedly that encapsulation was paramount to
> software quality, it's not always easy to let this go in favor of
> another technique, but I think the message is getting through and that
> more and more developers are becoming more aware of the pros and cons
> between "extreme OO" and "pragmatic testing".
> 
> In hindsight, I am absolutely shocked that all the teachers I had in
> school 20+ years ago that I had so much respect for had absolutely no
> inclination (and sometimes only contempt) for testing...

The #1 reason I don't reuse someone's code: I don't think it will work.
The #2 reason: I don't think I will be able to fit it into my design.

I would venture that the key property code needs in order to promote 
reuse is that it must be reliable. I can always add another Adapter.
